properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected Wednesday. Snow, heavy at times, is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The snow may also be mixed with rain at times. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are likely by Wednesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T02:16:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T10:17:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0575331949.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold and Blustery Week Ahead A transition to colder conditions will begin Tuesday across northern and central British Columbia. The cold air will persist through the end of the week with temperatures in the -15 to -25 range. Blustery northerly winds will accompany the arrival of the Arctic air with windchill becoming a factor Tuesday night and Wednesday. However, the Arctic air over the interior will deepen and temperatures will continue to drop Thursday and Friday. People working and spending time outside are reminded to dress warmly and in layers, preferably with a wind-resistant outer layer. Travellers are encouraged to add winter emergency kits to their vehicles which include a blanket, extra clothes and boots. For more cold weather preparedness tips, visit: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/seasonal-weather-hazards/be-prepared-for-winter.html#toc5 ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-26T13:31:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-25T21:32:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3233316603.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Clinton to 100 Mile House via Begbie Summit, Highway 97 - Pine Pass

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A winter storm with heavy snow and blowing snow is expected Wednesday. Snow, heavy at times, is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. Northeasterly winds gusting to 60 to 70 km/h will also produce blowing snow in exposed areas. Total snowfall amounts of 15 cm are likely by Wednesday evening with the heaviest snow falling in the afternoon. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T02:14:38-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected on Wednesday. Rain will begin Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm are possible by Wednesday evening. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible as the frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long duration rainfall expected Total rainfall amounts: 25 to 45 mm. Location: Cartwright to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: continuing until noon Wednesday. Remarks: While rainfall rates are not forecast to be heavy, significant amounts are still expected due to the long duration. Those travelling between communities should be on the lookout for localized flooding, minor washouts from runoff, and water pooling, especially in areas with higher existing snowpack. Some areas further inland and over higher elevations may also experience accumulating wet snow this morning and tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-27T01:17:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T09:18:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1207093238.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long duration rainfall expected Total rainfall amounts: 25 to 45 mm. Location: Norman Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: tonight through to noon Wednesday. Remarks: While rainfall rates are not forecast to be heavy, significant amounts are still expected due to the long duration. The highest amounts are expected to be between Mary's Harbour and Red Bay. Those travelling between communities should be on the lookout for localized flooding, minor washouts from runoff, and water pooling, especially in areas with higher existing snowpack. Some areas further inland and over higher elevations may also experience accumulating wet snow tonight and Tuesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Cold and Blustery Week Ahead A transition to colder conditions will begin Tuesday across central British Columbia. Arctic air will reach the coast by Wednesday night. Temperatures will dip below the freezing mark for most coastal communities. Blustery outflow winds will accompany the arrival of the Arctic air yielding cold wind chill values. The Arctic air will deepen throughout the week supporting temperatures and wind chill values down to the -5 to -10 range. People working and spending time outside are reminded to dress warmly and in layers, preferably with a wind-resistant outer layer. Travellers are encouraged to add winter emergency kits to their vehicles which include a blanket, extra clothes and boots. For more cold weather preparedness tips, visit: https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/seasonal-weather-hazards/be-prepared-for-winter.html#toc5 ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-26T13:32:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-25T21:33:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4015666667.2019

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Stuartburn
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-26T11:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-25T12:56:06-06:00, 2F0618D5-30C7-D5D0-AD63-2C7B7D29D0F7
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall is expected Wednesday. A developing low pressure system over Colorado is expected to track over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay late Wednesday. Snow is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The snow may be mixed with or change to rain Wednesday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts up to 15 cm are possible. There remains some uncertainty regarding the exact track of this system and associated snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required as the track of this low becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall for the middle of the week. Significant snowfall amounts and local blowing snow are expected over several regions of Quebec. For the moment, portions of Témiscamingue could receive up to 25 centimetres of snow while fifteen centimetres are expected over the other regions. An intense low pressure system from Colorado will reach Quebec on Wednesday. Snow will begin gradually Wednesday morning over Western Quebec, then will spread to central regions in the evening. The exact track of this weather system could still change, which could impact the type and amount of precipitation. The snowfall may make travelling difficult. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-26T19:43:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T03:44:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2484094019.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with the risk of freezing rain is expected Wednesday. A developing low pressure system over Colorado is expected to track over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay late Wednesday. Snow with risk of freezing rain is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The precipitation may also change over to rain Wednesday afternoon. Several hours of freezing rain are possible along with total snowfall amounts near 10 cm. There remains some uncertainty regarding the exact track of this system. This statement may be upgraded to a freezing rain warning as the track of this low becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong southerly winds will develop over Paulatuk late this afternoon. These winds are expected to combine with loose snow cover to produce blizzard conditions. The blizzard conditions will end on Wednesday morning when the winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-27T03:22:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-26T11:23:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2430739445.2019
Area: Paulatuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Periods of heavy snow will continue for Allison Pass tonight, as northerly flow brings several bands of moisture over the area. Local snowfall amounts will vary with the highest amount expected near Allison Pass. 18 cm of snow has fallen as of 6pm at Allison Pass, and total accumulation is still expected to be near 25 cm by Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with risk of freezing rain is expected Wednesday. A developing low pressure system over Colorado is expected to track over Lake Huron and Georgian Bay late Wednesday. Snow is expected to develop Wednesday morning and continue into Wednesday evening. The snow may be mixed with rain Wednesday afternoon. There is also the risk of freezing rain.
